summary: This is a court order from Judge J. Nathan in the case USA v. Maxwell, addressing scheduling for Ghislaine Maxwell's arraignment, initial appearance, and bail hearing. The order discusses conducting the proceeding remotely due to COVID-19 safety concerns and provides scheduling constraints from the Metropolitan Detention Center.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in criminal case 1:20-cr-00330-AJN, for whom an arraignment, initial appearance, and bail hearing are being scheduled.

persons.name: J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge who issued the order assigning the case to himself and providing instructions regarding remote proceedings and scheduling.

connections.description: Judge J. Nathan is presiding over the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell and issued this order regarding her upcoming court proceedings.

events.title: Government Request for Hearing
events.description: The Government, on behalf of the parties, requested via letter that the court schedule an arraignment, initial appearance, and bail hearing for Ghislaine Maxwell for the afternoon of Friday, July 10, 2020.

events.title: Court Order on Remote Proceedings
events.description: Judge J. Nathan issued an order addressing the scheduling of initial proceedings for Ghislaine Maxwell, noting COVID-19 safety issues and the possibility of remote proceedings if the defendant waives her physical presence.

events.title: Potential Video Appearance Date
events.description: The Metropolitan Detention Center protocols allow the defendant to be produced by video at 9:00 a.m. on this date for a remote proceeding.

events.title: Potential Video Appearance Date
events.description: The Metropolitan Detention Center protocols allow the defendant to be produced by video sometime during the morning of this date for a remote proceeding.

keyFacts: The criminal case is USA v. Maxwell, case number 1:20-cr-00330-AJN.
Judge J. Nathan has been assigned to the case for all purposes.
Initial proceedings (arraignment, initial appearance, bail hearing) were being scheduled, with consideration for remote video appearances due to the COVID-19 public health crisis.
The defendant, Ghislaine Maxwell, was asked to consider waiving her physical presence for the proceeding.
Scheduling constraints from the detention center limited potential video appearance times to July 9, 2020, at 9:00 a.m. or the morning of July 14, 2020.
